comment.author: 80413507@N08
comment._content: Just to th eright of the lady crossing the street is an unusually wide horse drawn cart. Any idea if it was a special piece of equipment?

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/80413507@N08] Maybe just the humvee of its day.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Bicycles, electric trams and lighting, looks like a similar date to this one of College Green: Over there, [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] dates those lights as latest 1903. According to the wikipedia page for Dublin trams, the Rathfarnham and Harold's Cross was electrified in November 1899.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/80413507@N08] That cart is a low level dray for barrels and drums.  It was mounted on a U shaped axle with a broad base to the U and was ideal for lifting heavy barrels, drums, baskets and the like in and out.  They were then moved about by handcart.

comment.author: 80413507@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie]  Thanks! although derangedlemur has a more interesting theory;)

comment._content: The Scene and the Fashions, especially the Cyclist in the bottom right remind me of Bloomsday - 16th June 1904 !!!!

comment._content: Historic 25" OSI

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: If you knew how fast any of the vehicles were going, you could establish the exposure time from the blurring, and from there you could probably date it based on the camera/film technology of the day. Science to the rescue!

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
Nelsons Pillar
In May 1876 a letter to the editor (Watty Cox's Irish Magazine) expressed its author's feelings in verse:
“In the centre of our city 
 Where the lines of traffic meet -
 In the very path of commerce,
 Blocking up a noble street -
 As a figure in a picture
 Disproportionately tall
 Seems to make its right surroundings
 Quite ridiculously small.”

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Nelson's head:

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: “In 1897 [Reckitt] negotiated the purchase of Mack’s Double Starch in this country and the colonies. Having acquired it, their chemists set about improving it and such considerable advance was made that it was decided to market the improved product as a powder under a new name – they called it Robin Starch – and it was an immediate success”. (Reckitt, Basil (1951). “The History of Reckitt and Sons Ltd”. London: A Brown & Sons). ... so this photo is post-1897

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
The famous large London Plane trees that lined the median for the second half of the 20th century were removed in 2003 amidst some controversy, with the oldest of these at the northern end planted c. 1903 being cut down in 2005 - all as part of an extensive regeneration scheme recently completed by Dublin City Council.

Cant be sure (with the resolution here - Carol?) but it does not look like there are trees in the median north of the Pillar, if correct would date us as pre 1903. 

Also, it does look like Summer.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: 8 October 1899 – Foundation stone of Parnell monument laid at Sackville Street by Daniel Tallon, Lord Mayor of Dublin. John Redmond was the instigator of the monument - Cant be sure but, I cant see any evidence of the monument??

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Definitely no trees there - they would get in the way of the tram cables. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] also suggested 1903 as a latest date based on lighting and 1899 as an earliest date based on electrification of Rathfarnham & Harold's Cross tram. Great detective work!

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] It's definitely summer. The sun height is about 50 degrees.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
Note the Coat of Arms within the Portico


The Greek hexastyle portico of the General Post Office, completed in 1818. The Royal Coat of Arms, similar to those at King's Inns and the Irish Houses of Parliament, was removed after independence.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Parnell Monument point may not be as good as first thought. The foundation stone was indeed laid in 1899, but the monument was not finished until 1911. There is a fantastic document on the history of all the Monuments in the O'Connell Street area (by Dublin City Council) see - History of Monuments It might be worth revisiting other photos of the area and applying the details found in this document.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Still believe that this photo was taken in Summer between 1899 and 1903

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] By the looks of it, History of Monuments should be bedside reading for every self-respecting Flickroonie! :) And on the back of your work on this one, we're now at circa 1899... Thanks Danny.

comment.author: 8420103@N05
comment._content: Re my suicide note in the picture, this is how Nelson looked from the viewing platform in his final days. Visitors completely caged in and him thinking himself safe up above. How wrong can you be?
